@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
 '''Elections in Ukraine''' gives information on [[election]] and election results in [[politics of Ukraine|Ukraine]]. 
 
-Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] - the [[president]] -  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (The Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a four year term. Until 2005, half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] and and the other half by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. Starting with the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada will be elected by proportional representation.
+Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] - the [[president]] -  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a four year term. Until 2005, half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] and and the other half by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. Starting with the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada will be elected by proportional representation.
 
 Ukraine has a [[multi-party]] system, with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which no one party often has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -12,6 +12,14 @@
 {{main|Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007}}
 {{Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007}}
 ===Election results compared with the previous Ukrainian parliamentary election===
+
+In 2006, 27% of the registered vote represented support for minor parties that received less then the 3% statutory representation threshold. In 2007 the number of voters that supported minor parties that received less then the 3% statutory threshold (Including the Socialist Party of Ukraine the support of 2.86%) was only 7%.
+
+The 20% difference shows a consolidation of voter's support towards major political parties. This fact needs to be taken into consideration when making any assessment as to the positive swing recorded for Bloc Yulia Tymoshenko, Party of Regions, The Communist Party of Ukraine and Bloc Lytvyn. The Our Ukraine bloc merged with the new party "People's Self-Defence" but only recorded a marginal gain in the overall percentage of the vote representing a reduction of 236964 votes in comparison with the 2006 data.
+
+Further review of the regional vote shows a consolidation of the vote by Yulia Tymoshenko in regions in which her party already maintained strong support. Apart from the Socialist Party of Ukraine and a marginal gain by Our Ukraine all major Political parties recorded an increase in the overall percentage the voter support when comparing the 2006 to 2007 results.
+
+The other fact that needs to also be considered is that in 2006 the participation rate was 67% and in 2007 the participation rate dropped down to 62%.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
 '''Elections in Ukraine''' gives information on [[election]] and election results in [[politics of Ukraine|Ukraine]]. 
 
-Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] - the [[president]] -  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five-year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a 5-year term (before a constitutional reform of 2004 this term was equal to 4 years). Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] and the other half by single-seat constituencies. Since the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada are elected by proportional representation.
+Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] - the [[president]] -  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five-year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (The highest legislatury or The Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a 5-year term (before a constitutional reform of 2004 this term was equal to 4 years). Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] and the other half by single-seat constituencies. Since the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada are elected by proportional representation.
 
 Ukraine has a [[multi-party]] system, with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which no one party often has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.

@@ -42,7 +42,7 @@
 ===Election results compared with the previous Ukrainian parliamentary election===
 
 In 2006, 27% of the registered vote represented support for minor parties that received less than the 3% statutory representation threshold. In 2007 the number of voters that supported minor parties that received less than the 3% statutory [[Election threshold|threshold]] (Including the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] the support of 2.86%) was only 7%.
-
+Amy Gill Matthew Gill
 The 20% difference shows a consolidation of voter's support towards major political parties. This fact needs to be taken into consideration when making any assessment as to the positive swing recorded for [[Bloc Yulia Tymoshenko]], [[Party of Regions]], The [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Bloc Lytvyn]]. The [[Our Ukraine]] bloc merged with the new party "[[Civil Movement "People's Self-Defense"|People's Self-Defence]]" but only recorded a marginal gain in the overall percentage of the vote representing a reduction of 236964 votes in comparison with the 2006 data.
 
 Further review of the regional vote shows a consolidation of the vote by [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] in regions in which her party already maintained strong support. Apart from the Socialist Party of Ukraine and a marginal gain by Our Ukraine all major political parties recorded an increase in the overall percentage the voter support when comparing the 2006 to 2007 results.

Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] and the other half by single-seat constituencies. Since the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada are elected by proportional representation.
+Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] - the [[president]] -  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five-year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a 5-year term (before a constitutional reform of 2004 this term was equal to 4 years). Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] and the other half by single-seat constituencies. Since the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada are elected by proportional representation.
 
 Ukraine has a [[multi-party]] system, with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which no one party often has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.

 '''Elections in Ukraine''' gives information on [[election]] and election results in [[politics of Ukraine|Ukraine]]. 
 
-Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] - the [[president]] -  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five-year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a 5-year term (before a constitutional reform of 2004 this term was equal to 4 years). Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 
 Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] - the [[president]] -  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five-year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a 5-year term (before a constitutional reform of 2004 this term was equal to 4 years). Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]]. In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] and the other half by single-seat constituencies. Since the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada are elected by [[party-list proportional representation]] with [[closed list]]s<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=Wp7VKL4p7kQC&pg=PA251&dq=%22Closed+list%22+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=Rf0sTMWxN4SbOJDX_aYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Closed%20list%22%20Ukraine&f=false Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics, And Institutional Design] by [[Paul D'Anieri]], [[M.E. Sharpe]], 2006, ISBN 0765618117 (page 251)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/65992/ Black Sea Fleet vote: Know thy turncoats], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/41069/ Ukraine needs constitutional change now], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 7, 2009)</ref> (the same goes for local elections<ref name=DemoWhat?>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/71677/ Parliament rejects bill on local elections under open lists], [[Kyiv Post]] (July 1, 2010)</ref>).
 
-Ukraine has a [[multi-party]] system, with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which no one party often has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
+Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which no one party often has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 
 Representative bodies and heads of [[local government]] throughout Ukraine are elected simultaneously with the Verkhovna Rada.

+==2010 local election==
+Local elections for local government were held on October 31, 2010.  {{Politics of Ukraine}}
 '''Elections in Ukraine''' gives information on [[election]] and election results in [[politics of Ukraine|Ukraine]]. 
 
-Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] ([[president]])  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five-year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a 5-year term (before a constitutional reform of 2004 this term was equal to 4 years). 
+Ukraine elects on national level a [[head of state]] ([[president]])  and a [[legislature]]. The president is elected for a five-year term by the people. The [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Parliament of Ukraine) has 450 members, elected for a 5-year term (before a constitutional reform of 2004 this term was equal to 4 years).<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20110201/162406293.html Ukrainian parliamentary elections postponed], [[RIA Novosti]] (February 1, 2011)</ref>
 
 Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]] (from each electoral district). Sharpe]], 2006, ISBN 0-7656-1811-7 (page 251)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/65992/ Black Sea Fleet vote: Know thy turncoats], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/41069/ Ukraine needs constitutional change now], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 7, 2009)</ref> (the same goes for local elections).<ref name=DemoWhat?>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/71677/ Parliament rejects bill on local elections under open lists], [[Kyiv Post]] (July 1, 2010)</ref>
 
+==Voter turnout==
+Since 1994 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections has been 68.13%<ref name="more 50">[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]]</ref><ref>[http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine]</ref> and for presidential elections 73%.<ref name="more 50"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}}</ref>

There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk is the only presidential candidate who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes in 1991. Most often participant of presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who took part in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than .1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. +
+

+

Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.
+
+Despite a clear system for declaring donations to campaign funds, officials and experts say that Ukraine’s election law is consistently flouted, with spending from candidates’ official funds representing only a fraction of the amount truly spent while it’s rarely clear where the funding comes from.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/57079/ More than $1 billion will be spent on campaign, but no one knows for sure], [[Kyiv Post]] (January 14, 2010)</ref>
+

+
+Voting analysis shows that during Ukrainian election there are traditional geographical voting patterns. [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (and his [[Party of the Regions]]) and [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] (and her party [[Bloc Yulia Tymoshenko]]) have been since about 2005 the main players in Ukrainian politics. Yanukovych traditional base of support is [[Ukraine|east]] and [[south Ukraine]], whereas Tymoshenko traditional base of support  is [[Ukraine|west]] and [[central Ukraine]]. Although this geographical division is decreasing.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/59340/ Election winner lacks strong voter mandate], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 11, 2010)</ref>

@@ -1,5 +1,4 @@
 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
-{{inuse}}
 '''Elections in Ukraine''' are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which often not a single party has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 ==Legislation==
 Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term. The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members, elected for a 4-year term.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20110201/162406293.html Ukrainian parliamentary elections postponed], [[RIA Novosti]] (February 1, 2011)</ref> In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/>

+===Past legislation===
+The parliamentary election law has been changed 4 times since 1991.<ref name="Law for POR?">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/114020/ Experts: Proposed election law casts cloud over next year’s parliamentary contest], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 3, 2011)</ref><ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/> Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]] (from each electoral district). In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006]] and [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|2007 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada are elected by [[party-list proportional representation]] with [[closed list]]s<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=Wp7VKL4p7kQC&pg=PA251&dq=%22Closed+list%22+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=Rf0sTMWxN4SbOJDX_aYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Closed%20list%22%20Ukraine&f=false Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics, And Institutional Design] by [[Paul D'Anieri]], [[M.E. Sharpe]], 2006, ISBN 0-7656-1811-7 (page 251)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/65992/ Black Sea Fleet vote: Know thy turncoats], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/41069/ Ukraine needs constitutional change now], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 7, 2009)</ref> (the same goes for local elections).<ref name=DemoWhat?>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/71677/ Parliament rejects bill on local elections under open lists], [[Kyiv Post]] (July 1, 2010)</ref>
 
 ==Voting patterns==
 Voting analysis shows that during Ukrainian election there are traditional geographical voting patterns. [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (and his [[Party of the Regions]]) and [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] (and her party [[Bloc Yulia Tymoshenko]]) have been since about 2005 the main players in Ukrainian politics. Yanukovych traditional base of support is [[Ukraine|east]] and [[south Ukraine]], whereas Tymoshenko traditional base of support  is [[Ukraine|west]] and [[central Ukraine]]. Although this geographical division is decreasing.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/59340/ Election winner lacks strong voter mandate], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 11, 2010)</ref>

Sharpe]], 2006, ISBN 0-7656-1811-7 (page 251)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/65992/ Black Sea Fleet vote: Know thy turncoats], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/41069/ Ukraine needs constitutional change now], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 7, 2009)</ref> (the same goes for local elections).<ref name=DemoWhat?>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/71677/ Parliament rejects bill on local elections under open lists], [[Kyiv Post]] (July 1, 2010)</ref>
 
@@ -27,6 +16,10 @@
 Since 1994 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections has been 68.13%<ref name="more 50">[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]]</ref><ref>[http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine]</ref> and for presidential elections 73%.<ref name="more 50"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}}</ref>
 
 The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where voted nearly 30.6 millions people and in 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk is the only presidential candidate who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes in 1991. Most often participant of presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who took part in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than .1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.
+==Perceived flaws in legislation==
+Despite a clear system for declaring donations to campaign funds, officials and experts say that Ukraine’s election law is consistently flouted, with spending from candidates’ official funds representing only a fraction of the amount truly spent while it’s rarely clear where the funding comes from.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/57079/ More than $1 billion will be spent on campaign, but no one knows for sure], [[Kyiv Post]] (January 14, 2010)</ref>
+
+Early May 2009 the "The Committee of Voters of Ukraine" stated they believe that the use of the state’s [[administrative resource]]s by [[List of political parties in Ukraine|political forces]] for their own national and local [[election campaign]]s is no longer a decisive factor in the outcome of Ukrainian elections.<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/196948.html Committee Of Voters: Use Of State’s Administrative Resources No Longer Decisive Factor In Outcome Of Elections], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (May 8, 2009)</ref> According to a survey of 2,000 people conducted in October 2010 by two Ukrainian nongovernmental organizations, the Democratic Initiatives Fund and [[OPORA]], one in five Ukrainians were willing to sell his or her vote in the then upcoming [[Ukrainian local elections, 2010|2010 Ukrainian local elections]].<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Survey_Shows_Every_Fifth_Ukrainian_Ready_To_Sell_Vote/2197889.html Survey Shows Every Fifth Ukrainian Ready To Sell Vote], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (October 22, 2010)</ref> But according to (then) [[Ukrainian Prime Minister]] [[Mykola Azarov]] these elections "were absolutely without the use of [[administrative resources]], naturally. Nobody interfered with our citizens."<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Yanukovychs_Party_Looks_To_Victory_Amid_Claims_Of_Election_Fraud_/2207495.html Yanukovych's Party Looks To Victory Amid Claims Of Election Fraud], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (November 01, 2010)</ref>
 ==Previous elections (national)==
 ===2012 parliamentary elections===
 {{main|Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012}}

 ==Legislation==

 In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/> The parliamentary election law has been changed 4 times since 1991.<ref name="Law for POR?">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/114020/ Experts: Proposed election law casts cloud over next year’s parliamentary contest], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 3, 2011)</ref><ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/> Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]] (from each electoral district). +From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%<ref name="more 50">[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]]</ref><ref>[http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine]</ref> The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary elections]] was the lowest ever with 57.99%;<ref name=turnout>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012)</ref> The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%).<ref name=turnout/> The voting turnout for Presidential elections is always higher than for Verkhovna Rada elections with an average voter turnout of 72% since 2004 (67.95% in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|last (2010) Presidential election]]).<ref name="more 50"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}}</ref>
 
 The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where voted nearly 30.6 millions people and in 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk is the only presidential candidate who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes in 1991. Most often participant of presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who took part in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than .1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.

 Early May 2009 the "The Committee of Voters of Ukraine" stated they believe that the use of the state’s [[administrative resource]]s by [[List of political parties in Ukraine|political forces]] for their own national and local [[election campaign]]s is no longer a decisive factor in the outcome of Ukrainian elections.<ref>[http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/196948.html Committee Of Voters: Use Of State’s Administrative Resources No Longer Decisive Factor In Outcome Of Elections], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (May 8, 2009)</ref> According to a survey of 2,000 people conducted in October 2010 by two Ukrainian nongovernmental organizations, the Democratic Initiatives Fund and [[OPORA]], one in five Ukrainians were willing to sell his or her vote in the then upcoming [[Ukrainian local elections, 2010|2010 Ukrainian local elections]].<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Survey_Shows_Every_Fifth_Ukrainian_Ready_To_Sell_Vote/2197889.html Survey Shows Every Fifth Ukrainian Ready To Sell Vote], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (October 22, 2010)</ref> But according to (then) [[Ukrainian Prime Minister]] [[Mykola Azarov]] these elections "were absolutely without the use of [[administrative resources]], naturally. Nobody interfered with our citizens."<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Yanukovychs_Party_Looks_To_Victory_Amid_Claims_Of_Election_Fraud_/2207495.html Yanukovych's Party Looks To Victory Amid Claims Of Election Fraud], [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] (November 01, 2010)</ref>

The participation of blocs of political parties was not allowed any more.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/117151/ Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 November 2011)</ref>

-====Election results compared with the previous Ukrainian parliamentary election====
-
-In 2006, 27% of the registered vote represented support for minor parties that received less than the 3% statutory representation threshold. In 2007 the number of voters that supported minor parties that received less than the 3% statutory [[Election threshold|threshold]] (Including the [[Socialist Party of Ukraine]] the support of 2.86%) was only 7%.
-
-The 20% difference shows a consolidation of voter's support towards major political parties. This fact needs to be taken into consideration when making any assessment as to the positive swing recorded for [[Bloc Yulia Tymoshenko]], [[Party of Regions]], The [[Communist Party of Ukraine]] and [[Bloc Lytvyn]]. The [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine]] bloc merged with the new party "[[Civil Movement "People's Self-Defense"|People's Self-Defence]]" but only recorded a marginal gain in the overall percentage of the vote representing a reduction of 236964 votes in comparison with the 2006 data.
-
-Further review of the regional vote shows a consolidation of the vote by [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] in regions in which her party already maintained strong support. Apart from the Socialist Party of Ukraine and a marginal gain by Our Ukraine all major political parties recorded an increase in the overall percentage the voter support when comparing the 2006 to 2007 results.
-
-The other fact that needs to also be considered is that in 2006 the [[Voter turnout|participation rate]] was 67% and in 2007 the participation rate dropped down to 62%.

In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] (faction vote) and the other half by single-seat constituencies. In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006]] and [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|2007 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada where elected by [[party-list proportional representation]] with [[closed list]]s[http://books.google.com/books?id=Wp7VKL4p7kQC&pg=PA251&dq=%22Closed+list%22+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=Rf0sTMWxN4SbOJDX_aYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Closed%20list%22%20Ukraine&f=false Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics, And Institutional Design] by [[Paul D'Anieri]], [[M.E. Sharpe]], 2006, ISBN 0-7656-1811-7 (page 251)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/65992/ Black Sea Fleet vote: Know thy turncoats], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 6, 2010)[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/opinion/op_ed/detail/41069/ Ukraine needs constitutional change now], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 7, 2009) (the same goes for local elections).[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/71677/ Parliament rejects bill on local elections under open lists], [[Kyiv Post]] (July 1, 2010) ==Voting patterns== +In elections of the sincew 2002 voters of Western and Central Ukrainian oblasts voted mostly for parties ([[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine]], [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"|Batkivshchyna]])[http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/WP406?PT001F01=900&pf7171=52 Центральна виборча комісія України - WWW відображення ІАС "Вибори народних депутатів України 2012"]
[http://en.for-ua.com/news/2012/08/30/111349.html CEC substitues Tymoshenko, Lutsenko in voting papers] and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yuschenko]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]) with a pro-Western and state reform [[Political platform|platform]], while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts of Ukraine voted for parties ([[Communist Party of Ukraine|CPU]], [[Party of Regions]]) and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yanukovych]]) with a pro-Russian and [[status quo]] platform. Although this geographical division is decreasing.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/59340/ Election winner lacks strong voter mandate], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 11, 2010) + +A 2010 study by the Institute of Social and Political Psychology of Ukraine found that in general, Yulia Tymoshenko supporters are more optimistic compared with Viktor Yanukovych supporters. 46 percent of the Tymoshenko’s backers expect improvement in their well-being in the next year compared to 30 percent for Yanukovych.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/57093/ Disappointment, pessimism high among nation’s voters], [[Kyiv Post]] (January 15, 2010) {{multiple image - |align=right + |align=left |image1=Вибори до ВР України 2002 по областях.png |width1=120 |caption1=[[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2002|2002 Parliament]] @@ -27,12 +30,13 @@ |width5=120 |image5=Другий тур 2010 по округах-en.png|thumb |caption5=[[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 President run-off]] - |width5=120 - |image5=Ukr elections 2012 onemandate okruhs.png|thumb - |caption5=[[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 Parliament]]}} -In elections of the sincew 2002 voters of Western and Central Ukrainian oblasts voted mostly for parties ([[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine]], [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"|Batkivshchyna]])[http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/WP406?PT001F01=900&pf7171=52 Центральна виборча комісія України - WWW відображення ІАС "Вибори народних депутатів України 2012"]
[http://en.for-ua.com/news/2012/08/30/111349.html CEC substitues Tymoshenko, Lutsenko in voting papers] and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yuschenko]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]) with a pro-Western and state reform [[Political platform|platform]], while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts of Ukraine voted for parties ([[Communist Party of Ukraine|CPU]], [[Party of Regions]]) and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yanukovych]]) with a pro-Russian and [[status quo]] platform. Although this geographical division is decreasing.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/59340/ Election winner lacks strong voter mandate], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 11, 2010) - -A 2010 study by the Institute of Social and Political Psychology of Ukraine found that in general, Yulia Tymoshenko supporters are more optimistic compared with Viktor Yanukovych supporters. 46 percent of the Tymoshenko’s backers expect improvement in their well-being in the next year compared to 30 percent for Yanukovych.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/57093/ Disappointment, pessimism high among nation’s voters], [[Kyiv Post]] (January 15, 2010) + |width6=120 + |image6=Ukr elections 2012 onemandate okruhs.png|thumb + |caption6=[[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 Parliament]] ([[constituencies]]) + |width7=120 + |image7=Ukr elections 2012 multimandate okruhs.png|thumb + |caption7=[[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 Parliament]] ([[Ukrainian_parliamentary_election,_2012#Changes_in_the_voting_system|nation-wide list]])}} +
==Voter turnout== From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]][http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine] The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary elections]] was the lowest ever with 57.99%;[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012) The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%). The voting turnout for Presidential elections is always higher than for Verkhovna Rada elections with an average voter turnout of 72% since 2004 (67.95% in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|last (2010) Presidential election]]).{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}}

@@ -2,6 +2,7 @@
 {{for|past election results in Ukrainian elections|List of Ukrainian elections}}
 '''Elections in Ukraine''' are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which often not a single party has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 ==Legislation==
+{{see also|Local government in Ukraine#Elections}}
 Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term. The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members, elected for a 4-year term.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20110201/162406293.html Ukrainian parliamentary elections postponed], [[RIA Novosti]] (February 1, 2011)</ref> In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/117151/ Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 November 2011)</ref>
 
 A [[snap poll]] must have a [[voter turnout]] higher than 50%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/156029.html|title=Voters Committee Predicting 60% Snap Election Turnout|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=16 October 2008|accessdate=16 October 2008}}</ref>

In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] (faction vote) and the other half by single-seat constituencies. In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006]] and [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|2007 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada where elected by [[party-list proportional representation]] with [[closed list]]s[http://books.google.com/books?id=Wp7VKL4p7kQC&pg=PA251&dq=%22Closed+list%22+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=Rf0sTMWxN4SbOJDX_aYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Closed%20list%22%20Ukraine&f=false Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics, And Institutional Design] by [[Paul D'Anieri]], [[M.E. [http://en.for-ua.com/news/2012/08/30/111349.html CEC substitues Tymoshenko, Lutsenko in voting papers] and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yuschenko]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]) with a pro-Western and state reform [[Political platform|platform]], while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts of Ukraine voted for parties ([[Communist Party of Ukraine|CPU]], [[Party of Regions]]) and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yanukovych]]) with a pro-Russian and [[status quo]] platform. Added a statement about Ukraine’s election law forbidding outside financing of political parties or campaigns.

Not Weaponised. The change is a factual addition regarding election law and does not employ weaponisation language or narratives.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -2,13 +2,13 @@
 {{for|past election results in Ukrainian elections|List of Ukrainian elections}}
 '''Elections in Ukraine''' are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which often not a single party has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 ==Legislation==
-{{see also|Local government in Ukraine#Elections}}
 Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term. The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members, elected for a 4-year term.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20110201/162406293.html Ukrainian parliamentary elections postponed], [[RIA Novosti]] (February 1, 2011)</ref> In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/117151/ Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 November 2011)</ref>
 
 A [[snap poll]] must have a [[voter turnout]] higher than 50%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/156029.html|title=Voters Committee Predicting 60% Snap Election Turnout|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=16 October 2008|accessdate=16 October 2008}}</ref>
 
 Ukraine’s election law forbids outside financing of political parties or campaigns.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/hacked-pr-documents-accelerate-political-war-318688.html Hacked PR documents accelerate political war], [[Kyiv Post]] (11 January 2013)</ref> 
 ===Local elections===
+{{more|Local government in Ukraine#Elections}}
 Under the [[Constitution of Ukraine]], the term of office of the heads of villages and towns and the council members of these villages and towns is five years.<ref name=IU162135yle>[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/cec-member-kyiv-city-council-to-be-elected-for-five-years-in-upcoming-election/ CEC member: Kyiv City Council to be elected for five years in upcoming election], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (16 February 2013)</ref>
 ===Past legislation===
 {{see also|Imperative mandate (provision in the Constitution of Ukraine)}}
llm_output:
Change: Added a "see also" link for local government elections in Ukraine.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change is a neutral wikification effort to improve the article's structure and does not contain any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ In the [[Ukrainian local elections, 2010|2010 Ukrainian local elections]] four years was set for the office of the heads of villages and towns and the council members of these villages and towns.[http://www.europarl.europa.eu/meetdocs/2009_2014/documents/afet/dv/201/201011/20101118_reportelecukr_en.pdf European Parliament EU-Ukraine PCC Members' delegation to Ukraine observing local and regional elections of 31 October 2010], [[European Parliament]] (10 November 2010) ==Voting patterns== -In elections of the sincew 2002 voters of Western and Central Ukrainian oblasts voted mostly for parties ([[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine]], [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"|Batkivshchyna]])[http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/WP406?PT001F01=900&pf7171=52 Центральна виборча комісія України - WWW відображення ІАС "Вибори народних депутатів України 2012"]
[http://en.for-ua.com/news/2012/08/30/111349.html CEC substitues Tymoshenko, Lutsenko in voting papers] and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yuschenko]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]) with a pro-Western and state reform [[Political platform|platform]], while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts of Ukraine voted for parties ([[Communist Party of Ukraine|CPU]], [[Party of Regions]]) and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yanukovych]]) with a pro-Russian and [[status quo]] platform. Although this geographical division is decreasing.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/59340/ Election winner lacks strong voter mandate], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 11, 2010) +In elections of the sincew 2002 voters of Western and Central Ukrainian oblasts voted mostly for parties ([[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc|Our Ukraine]], [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"|Batkivshchyna]])[http://www.cvk.gov.ua/pls/vnd2012/WP406?PT001F01=900&pf7171=52 Центральна виборча комісія України - WWW відображення ІАС "Вибори народних депутатів України 2012"]
[http://en.for-ua.com/news/2012/08/30/111349.html CEC substitues Tymoshenko, Lutsenko in voting papers] and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yuschenko]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]) with a pro-Western and state reform [[Political platform|platform]], while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts of Ukraine voted for parties ([[Communist Party of Ukraine|CPU]], [[Party of Regions]]) and presidential candidates ([[Viktor Yanukovych]]) with a pro-Russian and [[status quo]] platform.[http://books.google.com/books?id=H23Pv4Ik3vMC&pg=PA396&dq=Ukrainian++parties+pro-Western+Bloc&hl=nl&ei=8OdZTczRCMueOteptKIL&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CFMQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Ukrainian%20%20parties%20pro-Western%20Bloc&f=false Communist and Post-Communist Parties in Europe] by [[Uwe Backes]] and [[Patrick Moreau]], [[Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht]], 2008, ISBN 978-3-525-36912-8 (page 396) Although this geographical division is decreasing.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/59340/ Election winner lacks strong voter mandate], [[Kyiv Post]] (February 11, 2010) A 2010 study by the Institute of Social and Political Psychology of Ukraine found that in general, Yulia Tymoshenko supporters are more optimistic compared with Viktor Yanukovych supporters. 46 percent of the Tymoshenko’s backers expect improvement in their well-being in the next year compared to 30 percent for Yanukovych.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/57093/ Disappointment, pessimism high among nation’s voters], [[Kyiv Post]] (January 15, 2010) {{multiple image
llm_output:
Added a reference in the "Voting patterns" section.

Not Weaponised. The change is a simple addition of a reference and does not contain any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

+'''Elections in [[Ukraine]]''' are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which often not a single party has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 ==Legislation==
 Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term. The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members, elected for a 4-year term.<ref>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20110201/162406293.html Ukrainian parliamentary elections postponed], [[RIA Novosti]] (February 1, 2011)</ref> In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/117151/ Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 November 2011)</ref>

+{{more|Local elections in Ukraine}}
 Under the [[Constitution of Ukraine]], the term of office of the heads of villages and towns and the council members of these villages and towns is five years.<ref name=IU162135yle>[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/cec-member-kyiv-city-council-to-be-elected-for-five-years-in-upcoming-election/ CEC member: Kyiv City Council to be elected for five years in upcoming election], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (16 February 2013)</ref>
+
 ===Past legislation===
 {{see also|Imperative mandate (provision in the Constitution of Ukraine)}}
 The parliamentary election law has been changed 4 times since 1991.<ref name="Law for POR?">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/114020/ Experts: Proposed election law casts cloud over next year’s parliamentary contest], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 3, 2011)</ref><ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/> Before 1998 all the members of the Parliament were elected by single-seat [[constituency|constituencies]] (from each electoral district). In 1998 and in 2002 half of the members were elected by [[proportional representation]] (faction vote) and the other half by single-seat constituencies. In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2006|2006]] and [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|2007 parliamentary election]], all 450 members of the Verkhovna Rada where elected by [[party-list proportional representation]] with [[closed list]]s<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=Wp7VKL4p7kQC&pg=PA251&dq=%22Closed+list%22+Ukraine&hl=nl&ei=Rf0sTMWxN4SbOJDX_aYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Closed%20list%22%20Ukraine&f=false Understanding Ukrainian Politics: Power, Politics, And Institutional Design] by [[Paul D'Anieri]], [[M.E. @@ -2,7 +2,7 @@
 {{for|past election results in Ukrainian elections|List of Ukrainian elections}}
 '''Elections in [[Ukraine]]''' are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which often not a single party has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 ==Legislation==
-Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term. The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members and is also elected for a five-year term.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-18018002 Ukraine profile], [[BBC News]]</ref><ref>{{uk icon}} [http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/4061-17 Law of Ukraine "On Elections of People's Deputies of Ukraine " dated 17 November 2011], [[Verkhovna Rada]]</ref> In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/117151/ Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 November 2011)</ref>
+Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term.  A [[snap poll]] must have a [[voter turnout]] higher than 50%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/156029.html|title=Voters Committee Predicting 60% Snap Election Turnout|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=16 October 2008|accessdate=16 October 2008}}</ref>

@@ -55,7 +55,7 @@
 ==Voter turnout==
 From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%<ref name="more 50">[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]]</ref><ref>[http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine]</ref> The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary elections]] was the lowest ever with 57.99%;<ref name=turnout>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012)</ref> The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%).<ref name=turnout/> The voting turnout for Presidential elections is always higher than for Verkhovna Rada elections with an average voter turnout of 72% since 2004 (67.95% in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|last (2010) Presidential election]]).<ref name="more 50"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}}</ref>
 
-The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where nearly 30.6 millions people voted and in the 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk is the only presidential candidate who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes in 1991. Most often participant of presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who took part in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than .1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.
+The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where nearly 30.6 millions people voted and in the 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk is the only presidential candidate who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes in 1991. The person most frequently participating in presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who stood in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than 0.1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.

The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members and is also elected for a five-year term.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20031821 Q&A: Ukrainian parliamentary election], [[BBC News]] (23 October 2012)</ref><ref>{{uk icon}} [http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/4061-17 Law of Ukraine "On Elections of People's Deputies of Ukraine " dated 17 November 2011], [[Verkhovna Rada]]</ref> In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/117151/ Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 November 2011)</ref>

@@ -55,7 +55,7 @@
 ==Voter turnout==
 From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%<ref name="more 50">[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]]</ref><ref>[http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine]</ref> The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary elections]] was the lowest ever with 57.99%;<ref name=turnout>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012)</ref> The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%).<ref name=turnout/> The voting turnout for Presidential elections is always higher than for Verkhovna Rada elections with an average voter turnout of 72% since 2004 (67.95% in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|last (2010) Presidential election]]).<ref name="more 50"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}}</ref>
 
-The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where nearly 30.6 millions people voted and in the 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk is the only presidential candidate who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes in 1991. The person most frequently participating in presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who stood in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than 0.1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.
+The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where nearly 30.6 millions people voted and in the 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk and [[Petro Poroshenko]] are the only presidential candidates who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes, respective in 1991 and 2014. The person most frequently participating in presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who stood in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than 0.1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.

  |image1=Активность избирателей.svg|thumb

==Voter turnout== -From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]][http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine] The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary elections]] was then the lowest ever with 57.99%;[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012) The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%). In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|2014 parliamentary elections]] the official voter turnout was set (by the [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]) at 52.42%. This figure was determined after the Central Electoral Commission deducted the eligible voters in areas were voting was impossible. Because of the ongoing [[War in Donbass]] and the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|unilateral annexation]] of [[Crimea]] by [[Russia]], the 2014 parliamentary elections were not held in Crimea and also not held in parts of [[Donetsk Oblast]] and [[Luhansk Oblast]].{{cite news|date=22 May 2014|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|title=Ukraine elections: Runners and risks |publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=29 May 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140527092109/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|archivedate=27 May 2014}} The lowest turnout in these elections was in Donetsk Oblast (with 32.4%), the highest in again in Lviv Oblast (70%).[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/580903/ Voter turnout at Rada election 52.42% at all 198 constituencies], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (27 October 2014) According to [[Tadeusz Olszański]], of the [[Centre for Eastern Studies]], the low turnout in Donetsk Oblast (and also Luhansk Oblast) is explained by the end of an artificial increase of voter turnout there by [[Party of Regions]] officials. +From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]][http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine] The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary elections]] was then the lowest ever with 57.99%;[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012) The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%). In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|2014 parliamentary elections]] the official voter turnout was set (by the [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]) at 52.42%.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/231065.html Voter turnout at Rada election 52.42% at all 198 constituencies - CEC], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (27 October 2014) This figure was determined after the Central Electoral Commission deducted the eligible voters in areas were voting was impossible.{{Citation |first=Tadeusz A. |last=Olszański |title=A strong vote for reform: Ukraine after the parliamentary elections |publisher=OSW—Centre for Eastern Studies |date=29 October 2014 |url=http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2014-10-29/a-strong-vote-reform-ukraine-after-parliamentary-elections}} Because of the ongoing [[War in Donbass]] and the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|unilateral annexation]] of [[Crimea]] by [[Russia]], the 2014 parliamentary elections were not held in Crimea and also not held in parts of [[Donetsk Oblast]] and [[Luhansk Oblast]].{{cite news|date=22 May 2014|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|title=Ukraine elections: Runners and risks |publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=29 May 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140527092109/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|archivedate=27 May 2014}} The lowest turnout in these elections was in Donetsk Oblast (with 32.4%), the highest in again in Lviv Oblast (70%).[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/580903/ Voter turnout at Rada election 52.42% at all 198 constituencies], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (27 October 2014) According to [[Tadeusz Olszański]], of the [[Centre for Eastern Studies]], the low turnout in Donetsk Oblast (and also Luhansk Oblast) is explained by the end of an artificial increase of voter turnout there by [[Party of Regions]] officials. The voting turnout for Presidential elections is always higher than for Verkhovna Rada elections with an average voter turnout of 72% from 2004 till 2010 (67.95% in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Presidential election]]).{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}} In the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|2014 Presidential election]] the Central Election Commission of Ukraine set the turnout at over 60%; just as in the 2014 parliamentary elections, these elections were not held in Crimea and also not held in parts of Donetsk Oblast and Luhansk Oblast.[http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304811904579583413180447156 Poroshenko Declares Victory in Ukraine Presidential Election], [[The Wall Street Journal]] (25 May 2014) The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where nearly 30.6 millions people voted and in the 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk and [[Petro Poroshenko]] are the only presidential candidates who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes, respective in 1991 and 2014. The person most frequently participating in presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who stood in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than 0.1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each. {{multiple image

--- +++ @@ -63,7 +63,7 @@
==Voter turnout== -From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]][http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine] The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary elections]] was then the lowest ever with 57.99%;[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012) The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%). In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|2014 parliamentary elections]] the official voter turnout was set (by the [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]) at 52.42%.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/231065.html Voter turnout at Rada election 52.42% at all 198 constituencies - CEC], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (27 October 2014) This figure was determined after the Central Electoral Commission deducted the eligible voters in areas were voting was impossible.{{Citation |first=Tadeusz A. |last=Olszański |title=A strong vote for reform: Ukraine after the parliamentary elections |publisher=OSW—Centre for Eastern Studies |date=29 October 2014 |url=http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2014-10-29/a-strong-vote-reform-ukraine-after-parliamentary-elections}} Because of the ongoing [[War in Donbass]] and the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|unilateral annexation]] of [[Crimea]] by [[Russia]], the 2014 parliamentary elections were not held in Crimea and also not held in parts of [[Donetsk Oblast]] and [[Luhansk Oblast]].{{cite news|date=22 May 2014|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|title=Ukraine elections: Runners and risks |publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=29 May 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140527092109/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|archivedate=27 May 2014}} The lowest turnout in these elections was in Donetsk Oblast (with 32.4%), the highest in again in Lviv Oblast (70%).[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/580903/ Voter turnout at Rada election 52.42% at all 198 constituencies], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (27 October 2014) According to [[Tadeusz Olszański]], of the [[Centre for Eastern Studies]], the low turnout in Donetsk Oblast (and also Luhansk Oblast) is explained by the end of an artificial increase of voter turnout there by [[Party of Regions]] officials. +From 1994 till 2007 the average voter turnout for the Verkhovna Rada elections had been 68.13%[http://www.idea.int/vt/country_view.cfm?CountryCode=UA Country View Ukraine [[International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance]]][http://www.cvk.gov.ua Central Election Commission of Ukraine] The total voter turnout in the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary elections]] was then the lowest ever with 57.99%;[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/cec-turnout-in-ukraines-parliamentary-elections-5799-315149.html CEC:Turnout in Ukraine's parliamentary elections 57.99%], [[Kyiv Post]] (29 October 2012) The lowest turnout in these elections was in [[Crimea]] (with 49.46%), the highest in [[Lviv Oblast]] (67.13%). In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|2014 parliamentary elections]] the official voter turnout was set (by the [[Central Election Commission of Ukraine]]) at 52.42%.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/231065.html Voter turnout at Rada election 52.42% at all 198 constituencies - CEC], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (27 October 2014) This figure was determined after the Central Electoral Commission deducted the eligible voters in areas were voting was impossible.{{Citation |first=Tadeusz A. |last=Olszański |title=A strong vote for reform: Ukraine after the parliamentary elections |publisher=OSW—Centre for Eastern Studies |date=29 October 2014 |url=http://www.osw.waw.pl/en/publikacje/analyses/2014-10-29/a-strong-vote-reform-ukraine-after-parliamentary-elections}} Because of the ongoing [[War in Donbass]] and the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|unilateral annexation]] of [[Crimea]] by [[Russia]], the 2014 parliamentary elections were not held in Crimea and also not held in parts of [[Donetsk Oblast]] and [[Luhansk Oblast]].{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28931054|title=Ukraine crisis: President calls snap vote amid fighting|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=25 August 2014|accessdate=30 August 2014|archivedate=27 August 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140827104753/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28931054}}{{cite news|date=22 May 2014|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|title=Ukraine elections: Runners and risks |publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=29 May 2014|archiveurl=//web.archive.org/web/20140527092109/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27518989|archivedate=27 May 2014}} The lowest turnout in these elections was in Donetsk Oblast (with 32.4%), the highest in again in Lviv Oblast (70%).[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/580903/ Voter turnout at Rada election 52.42% at all 198 constituencies], [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (27 October 2014) According to [[Tadeusz Olszański]], of the [[Centre for Eastern Studies]], the low turnout in Donetsk Oblast (and also Luhansk Oblast) is explained by the end of an artificial increase of voter turnout there by [[Party of Regions]] officials. The voting turnout for Presidential elections is always higher than for Verkhovna Rada elections with an average voter turnout of 72% from 2004 till 2010 (67.95% in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Presidential election]]).{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}} In the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|2014 Presidential election]] the Central Election Commission of Ukraine set the turnout at over 60%; just as in the 2014 parliamentary elections, these elections were not held in Crimea and also not held in parts of Donetsk Oblast and Luhansk Oblast.[http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304811904579583413180447156 Poroshenko Declares Victory in Ukraine Presidential Election], [[The Wall Street Journal]] (25 May 2014) The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where nearly 30.6 millions people voted and in the 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. There were only three presidential candidates who have gathered over 10 millions votes: [[Leonid Kravchuk]] (1991 - 19.6, 1994 - 10.0), [[Viktor Yushchenko]] (2004 - 11.1), and [[Viktor Yanukovych]] (2004 - 11.0). The 10 million voters mark was almost reached by [[Leonid Kuchma]] in 1999, but he only managed to gain trust of 9.6 millions. To this day Kravchuk and [[Petro Poroshenko]] are the only presidential candidates who managed to win the elections after the first round obtaining over 50% of votes, respective in 1991 and 2014. The person most frequently participating in presidential elections is [[Oleksandr Moroz]] who stood in every presidential election since 1994 when he gained the biggest support of some 3.5 millions, while in 2010 for him voted less than 0.1 million. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each. {{multiple image
llm_output:
Change: Removed a reference to a news article from the BBC regarding the Ukraine crisis.

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change appears to be a minor edit related to citation formatting and does not introduce or remove any language that could be considered weaponising cultural heritage.

-The voting turnout for Presidential elections is always higher than for Verkhovna Rada elections with an average voter turnout of 72% from 2004 till 2010 (67.95% in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Presidential election]]).<ref name="more 50"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/business/22164|title=Swiss President, Luxembourg PM join others in congratulating Yushchenko|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=31 December 2004}}</ref> In the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2014|2014 Presidential election]] the Central Election Commission of Ukraine set the turnout at over 60%; just as in the 2014 parliamentary elections, these elections were not held in Crimea and also not held in parts of Donetsk Oblast and Luhansk Oblast.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/cec-chair-ukrainian-presidential-election-turnout-tops-60-percent-349393.html |title=CEC chair: Ukrainian presidential election turnout tops 60 percent |publisher=Kyivpost.com |date=26 May 2014 |accessdate=2 June 2014}}<ref><ref name="HP ">[http://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304811904579583413180447156 Poroshenko Declares Victory in Ukraine Presidential Election], [[The Wall Street Journal]] (25 May 2014)</ref> The most popular presidential elections were the first one in 1991 where nearly 30.6 millions people voted and in the 2004 election which gathered some 28 millions. Viktor Yanukiovych became the strongest runner-up in the history of presidential elections, while Leonid Kuchma - the only runner-up of the first round who managed to pull a win in the second one. Thus far the top two presidential candidates always would get support of over 5 million voters each.

 {{Politics of Ukraine}}
-
+[[File:Выборы на Украине 2007 (2).jpg|thumbnail|A woman with [[ballot]] during [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007]]]]
 '''Elections in [[Ukraine]]''' are held to choose the [[President of Ukraine|President]] ([[head of state]]), [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]] body), and [[Local government in Ukraine|local government]]s. [[Referendums in Ukraine|Referendums]] may be held on special occasions. Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which often not a single party has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 
 ==Legislation==

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 '''Elections in [[Ukraine]]''' are held to choose the [[President of Ukraine|President]] ([[head of state]]), [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]] body), and [[Local government in Ukraine|local government]]s. [[Referendums in Ukraine|Referendums]] may be held on special occasions. Ukraine has a [[multi-party system]], with numerous [[political parties|parties]] in which often not a single party has a chance of gaining power alone, and [[political parties|parties]] must work with each other to form [[coalition government]]s.
 
 ==Legislation==
-Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term. The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members and is also elected for a five-year term.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20031821 Q&A: Ukrainian parliamentary election], [[BBC News]] (23 October 2012)</ref><ref>{{uk icon}} [http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/4061-17 Law of Ukraine "On Elections of People's Deputies of Ukraine " dated 17 November 2011], [[Verkhovna Rada]]</ref> In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|last (2012) parliamentary election]] a mixed election system (50% under party lists and 50% under [[constituencies]]) was used.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/117151/ Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections], [[Kyiv Post]] (17 November 2011)</ref>
+Elections in Ukraine are held to choose the [[President]] ([[head of state]]) and [[Verkhovna Rada]] ([[legislature]]). The president is elected for a five-year term. The Verkhovna Rada has 450 members and is also elected for a five-year term, but may be dissolved earlier by the president in the case of a failure to form a government.<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111/><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20031821 Q&A: Ukrainian parliamentary election], [[BBC News]] (23 October 2012)</ref><ref>{{uk icon}} [http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/4061-17 Law of Ukraine "On Elections of People's Deputies of Ukraine " dated 17 November 2011], [[Verkhovna Rada]]</ref> Currently the Verkhovna Rara is elected using a [[Parallel voting|mixed election system]] with 50% of the representatives being elected from national [[Closed list|Closed party lists]], with a 5% threshold and 50% in [[constituencies]] using [[First-past-the-post voting]]. This system was adopted for the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 elections]]<ref name=newUKRelectionlawof171111>{{cite news|title=Parliament passes law on parliamentary elections|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/content/politics/parliament-passes-law-on-parliamentary-elections-117151.html|accessdate=9 August 2015|agency=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]|date=17 November 2011}}</ref> and was also used for the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2014|most recent (2014) election]], as a new draft law moving to electing all members using [[Open list|open party lists]] failed to gather necessary support in the Rada.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rada fails to put on today's agenda three bills on elections of MPs|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/218366.html|publisher=[[Interfax-Ukraine]]|accessdate=8 August 2015|date=14 August 2014}}</ref>
 
 A [[snap poll]] must have a [[voter turnout]] higher than 50%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/156029.html|title=Voters Committee Predicting 60% Snap Election Turnout|publisher=[[Ukrainian News Agency]]|date=16 October 2008|accessdate=16 October 2008}}</ref>
llm_output:
Changed the text to include additional details about the Verkhovna Rada's ability to be dissolved by the president and clarified the election system used.

Not Weaponised – The changes made are factual updates regarding the electoral process in Ukraine and do not contain any language that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.
